titleStmt.title: Letter, Andrew Jackson Donelson in Bolivar County, Miss. to his wife, Elizabeth 1858

publicationStmt.publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries Digital Initiatives

bibl.title: Letter, Andrew Jackson Donelson in Bolivar County, Miss. to his wife, Elizabeth 1858

projectDesc.p: Machine-readable transcription created for the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections.

editorialDecl.p: Errors in transcription of the printed text not controlled.
Editorial tags limited to gap and unclear.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

revisionDesc.change: Approximate date of original transcription and transcriber.
Migrating from P4 to validated TEI P5.

div.p: I am at the landruy to day for the meat which was shipped by the Touward, and not delivered on her downward trip. The negroes are all well, and will finish the cotton this week, except a few acres that are covered with water from the late season rains. There will be about 120 bales, The new overseer makes a good beginning and I hope will continue to do well. He has no family, and, if free from the vice of drinking cannot fail to make a good crop. Becca is spinning up the wool to make socks.

They are at work on the levy, and my creek will not disturb me any more, as soon as the levy is finished. As soon as I can ship my cotton I will do to New Orleans, but will be at home in about 2 or three weeks. I have not time to say more but will write again in a few days.
Mrs E A Donelson AJ Donelson
